title: How to Dry Basil in the Oven

steps.headline: Harvest no more than a third of the plant.
steps.description: If you harvest your basil leaves from the garden instead of buying them from the store, wait until the plant is 6–8 inches (15–20 cm) tall before you start picking any leaves. You can either pick off the leaves individually or cut off a whole stem, but make sure to harvest from the top down. Cut back no more than the top one third of the plant. If you choose to cut off the top of the plant, you’ll need to wait a few weeks before it’s ready to harvest again.

steps.headline: Remove the leaves from the stem.
steps.description: If you have a full stem of basil, strip off the individual leaves with your hands. Throw away any leaves that are dead or spotted. If you wish, you can keep the stems and use them as a flavorful additive in stock or stuffing, or infuse them into oil or vinegar to make a tasty dressing.

steps.headline: Rinse the leaves under cool water.
steps.description: Once you’ve removed the leaves from the stems, place them in a bowl or clean sink and run cool water over them. Stir them a little with your hands, then let them sit for a few minutes. Skim the floating leaves out of the water and spread them out on a dry towel.Safety precaution: The FDA recommends washing all herbs and produce under running water before you cook or eat it, even if you grew it yourself or bought it in a farmer’s market. Just use plain water—studies show there’s no benefit to using commercial produce washes. During rinsing, the dirt will sink to the bottom of the bowl. Don’t pour the contents of the bowl into a strainer, since this will simply dump the dirt back onto the leaves.

steps.headline: Let the leaves dry off after rinsing them.
steps.description: You can either let the basil air dry or gently pat it dry with a towel. Wait until the leaves have dried off completely before putting them in the oven, or they will cook instead of dry out. If you like, you can also gently roll the leaves up in a clean towel for a few minutes to absorb excess moisture.

parts.name: Putting the Basil in the Oven

steps.headline: Set the oven on the lowest temperature.
steps.description: When you’re ready to begin drying your basil, turn your oven on to the lowest possible setting, e.g., around 200 °F (93 °C). To keep the oven from getting too hot and singing your basil, it may also be helpful to leave the oven door slightly ajar.Tip: You can oven-dry the basil right after harvesting and cleaning it if you like, but some gardeners recommend allowing the basil to air-dry in a shady area for 3-4 days first. This will reduce the amount of time you need to leave it in the oven.

steps.headline: Spread the leaves on a parchment-lined baking sheet.
steps.description: While the oven is pre-heating, put some parchment paper on a baking sheet. Spread the leaves out on the parchment paper in a single layer. Try not to let the leaves overlap, since this will slow down the drying time. If possible, leave a little space between them.

steps.headline: Bake the leaves for 2-4 hours.
steps.description: Put the baking sheet in the oven on the top rack. Check the leaves frequently (e.g., every 15 minutes), especially as you approach the 2-hour mark, and turn them over occasionally with tongs to help them dry more evenly. The leaves are done when you can crumble them easily.

steps.headline: Crumble the dried leaves once they’re cool.
steps.description: Once the leaves are done drying, take them out of the oven and set them out to cool. After they’ve cooled completely, use your hands to crumble the dried leaves into small pieces. If you like, you can also grind the leaves with a mortar and pestle or in a spice grinder. Keep in mind, though, that ground herbs lose their flavor more quickly than whole or crumbled leaves.

steps.headline: Place the crumbled leaves in airtight containers.
steps.description: After crumbling the leaves, place them in an airtight container, such as a glass jar with a tightly sealed lid. To make sure your basil stays potent and flavorful for as long as possible, keep the jar in a dark, cool space (such as a cupboard or pantry) where it will be protected from heat and sunlight.Tip: To get the most out of your dried basil, gently rub it in the palm of your hand before adding it to a dish to help release its aroma and flavor. Add the basil at the beginning or middle of the cooking process rather than the end for the best flavor.

steps.headline: Use your dried basil within 1-3 years.
steps.description: With proper storage, your dried basil should last for 1-3 years before it begins to lose its flavor. You can tell if the basil is still good by crushing a little of it in the palm of your hand with your fingers, then tasting and smelling it. If you can’t really smell or taste anything, it has lost its potency. If your basil is completely dry, it should not actually spoil. Any residual moisture could lead to mold, however.
